patterns: is it recomended to speak from day one
why do I have to wait so long to speak
responses: Refold recommends focusing on comprehension first and not outputting till stage 3. Early output is the act of speaking or writing Japanese early. Everybody's journey is different, but the general recommendation is to not output until stage 3. There are many reasons we think this is the best route for most people. First, it gives you time to train your ear to properly hear the language. Second, it minimizes bad habits that can form by speaking improperly. Input helps inform good speaking, but speaking does not help inform comprehension or understanding. So focusing on understanding the language first has a double-dip effect helping improve your comprehension and speaking instincts. Trying to speak early does not double dip and is time spent only working on one skill. Speaking. And possibly improperly at that. Suppose you do, however, choose to ignore our advice or are in a situation where you can't wait to output (such as living in the country). In that case, we recommend only speaking with Natives. Two language learners speaking with each other is a recipe for compounding the harmful effects of early output.

patterns: How do I learn to speak
responses: Stage 3 articles go over this pretty extensively, I recommend starting there. Good luck!

patterns: where to talk to japanese speakers
where to find Japanese people to speak to
responses: Online forums, discords, and websites like italki.com are all places you can find natives to speak with. Also, try googling "language exchange apps" or look for language exchange meetups in Japanese near you on meetup websites.

patterns: How important is learning pronunciation early
responses: You don't really have to worry about pronunciation until you are in stage 3. Until then, focus on training your ear to hear the sounds correctly. This will ensure that you have the skills to properly correct your pronunciation once you reach stage 3 and begin speaking.
Refold recommends shadowing in stage 3 when you are ready to output. I've linked a video below going over Matt's thoughts on early shadowing.
Field-1: Why shadowing as a beginner is a waste
MattVsJapan goes over his thoughts on early shadowing.

responses: Shadowing is the act of mimicking native Japanese speakers in real-time to improve your output/speaking. I've linked some resources below to help you get started. Note that we don't recommend shadowing till stage 3, when you are ready to start outputting.

patterns: Should I find a speaking partner
responses: If you are in stage 3 and ready to start outputting, then yeah, it would be beneficial to find a speaking partner. However, we highly advise against speaking before stage 3 after you already have very high comprehension in the language.

patterns: where can I find a parent
where can I find a good language parent
responses:
Language parents are a stage 3 concept. You find someone with a lot of content that speaks how you want to speak and mimic them to get an output foundation. I will link the Refold article discussing language parents below.

To find a language parent can take some time. It is also not something you should worry about until you are in stage 3. This is because your comprehension wont be high enough before then to even know if the parent you are selecting speaks how you want to speak. But if you are ready for a parent, here are some resources. Either hunt for one on your own, or head on over to <#800190781549838346> and see what others have shared or ask for recommendations. The Refold Japanese community document also has parent recommendations, so check out what's available there as well. (If you can not see the <#800190781549838346> channel, gain access by heading over to <#783082970432536608> and reading the rules of the media share channels)
